title: world-champion-sprinter-maria-lyle-thanks-her-mum-for-rekindling-her-love-of-athletics
story: Maria Lyle ed from the Fazza International Championships in Dubai recently with two gold medals.However, it was just last year that she broke down in tears during her ldquodarkest moment before a major competition.The teenager has lived with diplegic cerebral palsy in her legs almost all her le.The -year-old told the Courier that her mum Susan had been with her throughout her journey, which has seen her represent Great Britain in the Paralympics and Scotland in the Commonwealth Games.Her mum is a PE teacher at Dunbar Primary School and taught Maria.Keen for Maria to be involved as much as her peers, but with little experience of teaching pupils with a disability, Susan looked for ways to deliver lessons which allowed Maria to flourish.Maria said: ldquoWhen I was younger, I struggled quite a lot. Things didnrsquot come quite as naturally for me as they did for my peers and often I ended up feeling a bit rubbish about myself.ldquoThings drastically changed, however, after one PE lesson. We had to complete the multi-stage fitness test .ldquoAs someone who fell over constantly and ended up with cut knees  per cent of the time, you could say I wasnrsquot that keen to join the lesson.ldquoTo everyonersquos surprise, I was the last one left in the test. That was the first time Irsquod ever felt such a sense of achievement. From that moment, running would become a big part of my le.Those short runs started to build Mariarsquos strength.She became European champion in  and within the next four years Paralympic, World and Commonwealth medals followed.But despite all her success, Maria couldnrsquot find the same love for her sport as she had during those early runs with her mum. The teenager became overwhelmed with worry about competing and her concerns impacted her le away from the track.After suffering in silence for years, Maria finally opened up to her mum, who convinced her to seek professional help. She was later diagnosed with having anxiety.Maria, who works at the Scottish Parliament as a committee assistant, said: ldquoMy mum would give up lots of her time, she would lead my sessions and drive me all over the country so I could compete. She would even take time off work to watch me in competitions. Because of this I would get worriedI didnrsquot run well.ldquoIrsquod feel guilty about wasting her time. Disappointing my mum wasnrsquot the only thing I was anxious about. I was worried about my competitors and factors I couldnrsquot control.ldquoBefore the  European Championships, I revealed something to my mum that I had never spoken about before. I broke down and cried for hours expressing how rubbish I felt about myself in both my running and personal le.ldquoRunning had completely taken over and there was nothing positive.ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me.ldquoShe was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me. From that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.Susan said that no medal ceremony could compare to seeing her daughter enjoying running again. She said: ldquoMy proudest moment is not Maria winning medals on the world stage, it is probably Maria competing in Glasgow last weekend at the  National Indoor Championships.ldquoFor the first time in years, I saw Maria stand on the start line feeling relaxed and running through the finish line with a smile on her face.ldquoAlong with the support from us as a family and her coach, Jamie Bowie, Maria has turned herself around and is back on track in all areas of her le.

title: little-support-for-idea-of-public-wi-fi-in-town-centres
story: A report to East Lothian Council revealed that moves to increase access to a fast, free public internet service did not win favour with residents.Despite the lack of support, council officers are pushing ahead with their strategy to introduce it across towns in the county.The report into the local authorityrsquos town centre strategy revealed the results of public consultations over a range of actions proposed within the communities.It said: ldquoFor each town centre there was overall support for all the proposed actions, with the exception of the introduction of public Wi-Fi in each town centre, except Haddington which already has public Wi-Fi.In Musselburgh, two-thirds of respondents disagreed with a proposal to introduce it in the town centre, with less than a third agreeing in Tranent. The reaction was similar in Prestonpans and North Berwick, while Dunbar saw the least support, with only one in five backing it.In the majority of towns, the most support was to use statutory action to force private owners of buildings in multiple ownership to have external repairs carried out.Among comments about public Wi-Fi relayed to councillors, one person said: ldquoI really find it surprising that town Wi-Fi has been identied as a possible benefit for the town centre. With excellent G coverage in the town, this would perhaps be more suited at the end of the list of improvements.Another added: ldquoI donrsquot think lack of public Wi-Fi is an issue with G cover widely available.But the council responded: ldquoThe council notes that even with  per centsuperfast broadband coverage [the same goes for G G], affordability will remain a signicant challenge. Consequently, there will still be a requirement for free Wi-Fi across our communities.

title: musselburgh-golf-club-hopes-to-attract-more-women-members
story: Head professional Norman Huguet will lead lessons for women interested in learning to play golf and they will also get the chance to practise their skills on the clubrsquos stand-alone par  beginnersrsquo course.Committee member Linda Smith has organised the initiative, which starts with an open event at the club next Sunday , -pm and -pm.Women can join others also considering taking up golf in a relaxed atmosphere. Everyone is entered into a draw for a free afternoon tea at the club.A block of six lessons for one hour a week then start in April, with clubs provided and trainers allowed. During this time, players have full access to the beginnersrsquo course and all other practice areas.The tuition for a maximum of  women is held on a Tuesday, starting on April , and also on a Wednesday, beginning April , -pm. More classes will be organisedthere is demand.Linda said: ldquoWe want to give people an easy and cheap way to try golf.ldquoPeople might think they need to get golf shoes and equipment. If you decide you want to play, yoursquod get those things over time but, to try golf, you donrsquot need them as we will provide the clubs. We want to take away those barriers.ldquoThere might be a lot of women who would like to try golf but donrsquot know how to go about it.ldquoGroup lessons are a nice way for women to learn and, once the lessons are finished, they have a nice, ready-made group of people that they know in the golf club. So,they go on to join the club, they have people they can play with.ldquoWe will make sure the ladies, during the lessons and after, are integrated into the club. That is something we want to focus on because there is playing on the golf course but there is the golf club which is a dferent thing.ldquoPeople can come into the clubhouse and enjoy the tray bakes and scones, have a coffee and a chat with people, and meet new friends.Linda said the ladiesrsquo section was small with just over  members who play.She added: ldquoDuring the six-week lessons, lady members will help with the lessons and then we can go for a tea or coffee after, so people will be comfortable coming into the clubhouse.ldquoExisting members will also play with the ladies involved in the lessons on the six-hole course.ldquoThe six-hole par- course is great. No one is going to go and watch you playing there. If you miss-hit the ball, which you will when you are learning, there is no one to see you other than other learners.ldquoIt is a non-scary place to learn to play golf.ldquoWe are a really friendly club and people will be made very welcome. If people like it, after the six-week period, they can join the six-hole course or join and be able to play on the championship course.ldquoWe are just hoping that there are enough people out there who want to come and learn.Linda stressed that there were dferent s mapped out on the championship course, including a shorter blue course.Linda said: ldquoThey can play thethey feel is suitable for them.ldquoWe want people to come in and make new friends and use the clubhouse facilities.ldquoIf people want to come and only focus on getting their handicaps down because they are competitive golfers, thatrsquos great as well and there are places for that. Those people donrsquot need these group lessons.Linda added that golf was social, provided exercise in the fresh air and the chance to see wildle and the seasons change.Anyone interested to going along to the open event or to find out more about the package, which costs pound, email sec retary@themusselburghgolf club or call   .

title: sir-cliff-richard-backs-pressure-group-pushing-for-anonymity-reform
story: In  his Berkshire home was raided by police, which was covered by the BBC and included the deployment of a TV helicopter, and led to him being publicly named.No arrests were made in relation to the accusation against Sir Clf, and he did not face charges.Sir Clf is now backing Falsely Accused Iniduals for Reform , a new pressure group that is pushing for anonymity for those accused of sexual offences until there is a charge.ldquoBeing ly accused myself and having that exposed in the media was the worst thing that has happened to me in my entire le, Sir Clf said.ldquoEven though untrue, the stigma is almost impossible to eradicate.ldquoHence the importance of Fairrsquos campaign to change the law to provide for anonymity before charge in sexual allegations and hence my continued work with Fair in the future.ldquoHad this proposed change in the law been enacted when the police decided to raid my apartment following the allegations of a fantasist, the BBC would not have been able to film this event, name me,and so plunge my le and those close to me into fear and misery.He previously said that the trauma of the coverage left him emotionally drained. The singer has since sued the BBC for invasion of privacy ndash winning pound, in damages.Daniel Janner QC, whose father was the late Labour peer Lord Janner, is the founder and secretary of Fair.The group strongly believes in anonymity up until charge, and is also calling for a change in the language of criminal proceedings from victims to complainants.Mr Janner described Sir Clfrsquos support as an ldquoenormous boost to our important work.ldquoIt is a privilege and honour that Sir Clf has added his support. We campaign to re-balance the scales of justice to protect those ly accused, he said.ldquoAt present we are concentrating our efforts to change the law to provide for anonymity until charge for those accused of sexual offences.Other Fair supporters include broadcaster Paul Gambaccini who was arrested in October  over a claim he sexually assaulted two teenage boys as part of Operation Yewtree, set up in the wake of the revelations about paedophile Jimmy Savile.The -year-old, a regular fixture on the airwaves for decades, spent a year on bail before the case was dropped.Former Tory MP Harvey Proctor had his home raided and was publicly named, and is also a supporter of the pressure group.He was investigated as part of Scotland Yardrsquos doomed sex abuse probe Operation Midland that centred on claims boys were sexually abused by a number of public figures more than  years ago.The investigation was abandoned amid widespread criticism, with the -year-old spending more than a year facing accusations he was a child murderer and rapist before he was finally cleared.

title: john-mcdonnell-says-labour-is-preparing-for-government
story: While Labour have been trailing the Conservatives in the polls, Mr McDonnell said: ldquoWe need another two to three points to take us into government and that is what we will get when we go into that campaign.With Theresa Mayrsquos Tories no longer having a Commons majority, the shadow chancellor said that Parliament ldquois so unstable it is completely unpredictable.And he told a fringe event at the Scottish Labour conference in Dundee that he and Jeremy Corbyn were already preparing for government.While he accepted it was ldquoalmost impossible for Labour to force a general election under the current system of fixed term parliaments, Mr McDonnell said: ldquoJust in case there is an election we are preparing for an election, wersquove got all the campaign plans ready. Wersquove been testing messaging, wersquove got the grid ready to go.ldquoThe grid is who goes where in terms of shadow cabinet all round the country, where Jeremyrsquos rallies are going to be, sothere is a general election we go straight into election mode.Mr McDonnell also told Labour activiststhat as part of the preparations he was now considering his first budget.He said: ldquoIrsquom going through a first budget exercise, so Irsquom sitting down with all the shadow cabinet teams to talk about their plans, costing them and then look at priorities.ldquoWersquore in that situation where literally wersquore preparing for government, wersquore preparing for the election.

title: scottish-government-must-have-role-in-future-trade-negotiations-committee-says
story: A report by the Scottish Affairs Committee called for devolved administrations to be closely involved in each stage of negotiating UK trade deals to ensure that trade agreements work for the whole of the UK.It called on theUK Government to commit to including representatives from the devolved administrations in the UK negotiating team for future trade agreements, with the understanding that devolved ministers will not deviate from the UK Government negotiating position.The committee also urged Westminster to ensure that sectors of vital importance to the Scottish economy such as the food, drink and fisheries sectors are not traded away to secure preferential agreements for other industries.It also said that ensuring Scottish producers enjoy the protection of Geographical Indicatorsstatus, which protects products such as Scotch whisky,Scotch beef and Stornoway Black Pudding against illegal imitation, must be a ldquored line for the UK in all its future trade negotiations.Pete Wishart MP, chairman of the committee, said: ldquoThe Government has the immense task of setting a precedent for all future international trade talks post-Brexit.ldquoMy committee heard evidence that Scotland needs a place at the negotiating tableUK trade deals are to stand a chance of benefiting the whole of the UK.He added: ldquoScotlandrsquos food and drink and services sectors have benefited enormously from the single market, and the same benefits must be secured for the future.ldquoThese industries cannot be allowed to become an afterthought in tense trade talks.ldquoThe opportunities from boosting Scottish exports should be front and centre of UK trade policy and strategy.The report was published following an in-depth inquiry with evidence sessions hearing from academics, international trade experts, Scottish businesses, and UK and Scottish Government ministers.In , total exports from Scotlandwere estimated to have been worth pound. billion to the Scottish economy, of which pound. billion were international.The EU was Scotlandrsquos largest international export region accounting for % of all international exports, followed by North America at %.The report argues that sectors of vital importance to the Scottish economy such as food, drink and fisheries havebenefited immensely from membership of the EU Single Market and recommends that the UK Government consult with business before any decisions to erge from EU trading standards are made.It also urged Westminster to ensure thatno new barriers to trade are created between Scotland and the rest of the UK.The committee also recommended thatthe UK Government explore the option of establishing an international trade sub-committee at the Joint Ministerial Council to ensure devolved administrations have a role in setting UK trade mandates.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoWhile trade remains a reserved matter, the UK Government is committed to working closely with all the devolved administrations to deliver a future trade policy that works for the whole of the UK.

title: footage-reveals-cracks-in-ayrshire-nuclear-reactor
story: The unit at Hunterston B in North Ayrshire has not been operating since the cracks were found to be growing faster than expected.A planned inspection of the graphite bricks that make up the core of reactor threein March last year uncovered new ldquokeyway root cracks.EDF Energy said these have now grown to an average of mm wide.The firm has released footage of the cracks, which was taken in  and .Station director Colin Weir told BBC Scotland: ldquoNuclear safety is our overriding priority and reactor three has been off for the year so that we can do further inspections.ldquoWersquove carried out one of our biggest ever inspection campaigns on reactor three, wersquove renewed our modelling, wersquove done experiments and tests and wersquove analysed all the data from this to produce our safety case that we will submit to the Office for Nuclear Regulation.ldquoWe have to demonstrate that the reactor will always shut down and that it will shut down in an extreme seismic event.

title: Iain Macwhirter  28 days to go and Westminster won   t even reject no deal  let alone back a People   s Vote
story: I could give you a pious expression of naive hope. Tell you that therersquos going to be a referendum on Brexit, that the ERG are back in their box, Jezza has finally come good, and Theresa May has been put in a secure unit. But I canrsquot in all honesty agree with commentators, like the blessed Polly Toynbee, who believe we are now on the road to redemption.Yes, Labour did repeat its promise to hold a referendumJeremy Corbynrsquos ldquoworkable plan of a permanent customs union is rejected ndash as it was in one of last weekrsquos many meaningless votes. Oh, and Labour will support a referendumthere is no General Election. Anda no deal Tory deal looks likely. If, , .ButLabour really wanted to eliminate the threat of no deal, it would have moved heaven and earth to deliver the SNPrsquos motion calling for precisely that.Looking back on this dismal week, the standout, surely, is the arrant insanity of Parliament ndash a rational body of elected representatives ndash failing to take the opportunity to rule out an event which would put the army on the streets, interrupt food and medicine supplies, and cause the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.Yes, the Yvette Cooper Oliver Letwin amendmentwas endorsed by Parliament overwhelmingly, after Theresa May gave it the nod. This means that there will be an extension to Article Parliament doesnrsquot support a deal by March . Well and good. If therersquos one thing the UK Parliament is supremely good at itrsquos failing to agree.It doesnrsquot like Mayrsquos botched deal, the Norway option, EFTA or any other solution that Brussels thinks acceptable. So that means an extension is inevitable. Except that the French president Emmanuel Macron and the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, have made clear that the  countries of the EU , will only contemplate delaying Britainrsquos departure from the EUit is for ldquoa purpose. Holding more meaningless votes, staging more ministerial resignations and arguing on College Green outside Parliament do not, one suspects, constitute a legitimate purpose.Still, everyone seems convinced that an extension is in the bag. This led to largely unwarranted excitement on the Remain side. With Labour calling for a Peoplersquos Voteand Theresa Mayrsquos deadline finally breached, Twitter went into orbit. Lord Adonis all but declared victory in the Battle of Brexit. Europhiles were dancing in the streets, metaphorically at least, and jeering at the nasty Brexiters who had been defeated by the forces of good. It was like the last reel of Lord of the Rings.But such triumphalism was premature. Much as I wish it were the case, there is still no majority in Parliament for a referendum. Stephen K Bush, the political editor of the New Statesman, has been counting them out and counting them back in again and he is adamant that the Labour Brexit rebels will prevent any motion for a referendum passing through Parliament. He says at least  Labour MPs are opposed. Hersquos right.ldquoRebels here is something of a misnomer since there is widespread belief that Brexit is the outcome desired by their leader. Indeed, on one interpretation of last weekrsquos events, Jeremy Corbyn has managed to find a way to secure Brexit while also appearing to support a referendum. This is because what is called the Kyle Wilson amendment.This cross-party proposal, which Labour is minded to support on March , calls for MPs to agree to Theresa Mayrsquos deal , but only on the condition that there is a referendum to validate it. Bingo. Labour can tell all its working-class Brexit supporters in target marginals that, yes, it didnrsquot block Brexit. But Jeremy can also curry favour with the Remainiacs of Islington by appearing to support a Peoplersquos Vote.Itrsquos very clever, but to my mind somewhat bonkers. Why would Labour help pass Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which Jeremy Corbyn has said is worse than no deal, would lose thousands of jobs and would lock the UK into a backstop from which it cannot escape  At least this is what he has said repeatedly in the Commons.Surely, a vote is a vote. Theresa May could legitimately say that her deal has been endorsed by Parliament, and call on Labour to campaign for it in any referendum. Not that she has the slightest intention of calling a referendum.Theresa Mayrsquos strategy is the same as it ever was: not listening, nothing has changed, take it or leave it. It pains me to say it, but the Prime Minister at least has a strategy. It is to run down the clock, while allowing the ious tribes in Parliament and in her Cabinet, to fall out among themselves.Itrsquos working. Labour is moving ever more in the direction of her deal, however much they may deny it. Parliament canrsquot agree on anything.There are tears in Cabinet and more resignations ndash  from the Government so far. But whorsquos counting  The European Research Group ndash that comically misnamed faction of extreme Brexiters ndash has reportedly split over William Rees-Moggrsquos equivocation on the Irish backstop.And while all about is chaos and acrimony, so ticks away the clock until Brexit day. Twenty-eight days at the time of writing. Goodness me, is that really the time  Yes it is. As in the film of the same name, the zombies are stirring.I accept that is an offensive way to describe Nigel Faragersquos ldquoBrexit Betrayal march from Sunderland to London. But it could get nasty on the road.What do I think will happen in the end  As Irsquove been saying in this column since Christmas, I think Parliament will block a no-deal Brexit. There will be an extension of Article , and Labour will probably end up backing Mayrsquos deal, or abstaining on it which amounts to the same thing.If Labour, by some remote chance, continues to reject Mayrsquos deal or its iants, in the meaningful vote on the inglorious twelfth, then I think MPs would still reject a referendum. There is still no majority for one, and Labourrsquos die-hard Brexiters are not for turning.Which makes the most likely option ndash about the only one Theresa May can authorise as PM under her prerogative powers ndash would be to revoke Article . Pull the plug. End it.OK, so thatrsquos wishful thinking on my part. Her Government would fall and precipitate an election. But looking at the chaos that is Brexit, and the lack of time, it seems as good a shout as any, especiallyBrussels reject a meaningless extension.If Britain canrsquot decide how to leave the EU, an extension to Article  would be pointless. The sensible thing to do would be to cancel Brexit, go away, and think again.

title: what-it-feels-like-to-have-a-stammer
story: The most dficult thing for a person with a stammer to say is their own name. I was often asked to introduce myself and thatrsquos when it would happen. Thatrsquos when I would crumble. The easiest way to describe it is the iceberg effect. At first glance, above the waterline people might not even notice a stammer, but below the surface where people canrsquot see, it can impact everything.My stammer wasnrsquot an issue at first. It developed in my early childhood when I was told that there was a problem with my pronunciation. I was five years old at the time but it didnrsquot control my le. My school report cards always said that I was talkative, confident and participated in all of the classroom activities. I was even given a leading role in a school production.Le changed when I made the move from a small primary school of  pupils to a high school with  people. I sat in class avoiding all eye contact with the teacher, fearing the dreaded moment that I would be asked a question. Jokes were often made by other pupils about my stammer which only made matters worse. I felt misunderstood and it completely ruined my self-esteem. The teachers didnt understand my stammer and some werent even aware that it was a condition. They just assumed that I was nervous.My behaviour soon became self-destructive. My class was asked to take part in a work shadowing competition were the top ten reports would be selected and the winners were expected to give a presentation in front of everyone. I couldnt think of anything worse. I took matters into my own hands and purposely sabotaged my report by adding in mistakes to ensure that I wouldnrsquot be picked.I used to be a teacher, I ended up homeless - football saved my leWhen I was studying at university, I worried about everything from being knocked back on nights out with my friends to buying train tickets. I thought that I would never get a job or make anything of my le. I had a good circle of friends, but it was always in the back of my mind that I was going to be made fun of by others. It reached the point were I knew that I had to take charge of the situation and not allow it to take over my le any more.Although there are speech therapists, there isnt a great deal of support for people living with stammers. I set up a support group in  for other people with the same concerns. People from all walks of le attend and share their stories. Each monthly session looks at ways to cope with everyday situations that stammers can make dficult. It explores ways to desensitise stammering, build peoplersquos confidence and help them manage stress.At one point, speaking situations were the first thing on my mind in the morning and the last thing on my mind at night. Now, I work for the NHS in a job where Irsquom required to speak in public and give presentations. Irsquom at a stage where I often find that I actually enjoy public speaking which is something I never thought Irsquod say. Irsquove learned how to overcome my stammer by reaching out and connecting with others.Visit stammeringscotland.orgSOPHIE MCLEAN

title: unspun-the-political-diary

title: richard-leonard-labour-cannot-rely-on-snp-delcine
story: The Scottish Labour leader will say there is no ldquoiron law that the SNPrsquos popularity will wane before the next Holyrood election in , and winning will take a hard fight.Even after being out of office for  years, he will say Scotland Labour is only now ldquogetting back to where we should have been in terms of traditional support.A Panelbase poll this week showed support for Scottish Labour continuing to slide.On the second of three days in Dundee, Mr Leonard will also highlight the cityrsquos industrial closures as he calls for a more progressive agenda for workersrsquo rights.Michelin closed its tyre factory in November with the loss of  jobs, while the construction services firm McGill and Co went into administration last month, axing almost  jobs.Referring to Scottish Labourrsquos route back to power, Mr Leonard will say: ldquoWe cannot rely on an automatic disillusionment with the SNP to do the job for us. There is no iron law, there is no inevitability. Butwe work for it, industrially and politically, we can achieve it.ldquoBecause I tell you that we make our own history. We are getting back to where we always should have been, the party of communities and the party of workers.He will tell delegates at the Caird Hall about meeting McGill workers a few weeks ago.ldquoThey told me they had been let down: badly let down by the companyrsquos bank which foreclosed an overdraft and badly let down by the Scottish Government, which could have stepped in to rescue these jobs, but who sat back.ldquoThe SNP tell us we shouldnrsquot talk about workersrsquo rights because they are reserved. But [bad] practices are commonplace on public contracts funded by the Scottish Government.ldquoIt is about time we had a Scottish Government prepared to use its powers, including through public procurement to drive up employment standards and working practices on these contracts to build our hospitals, our roads, and our railway infrastructure.

title: corbyns-constitutional-adviser-tells-him-to-create-partnership-government-with-scotland
story: Baroness Pauline Bryan of Partick appointed by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn last year explicitly to develop the partyrsquos constitutional policy, is recommending greater devolution of power to Scotland - by ensuring the future relationship between Holyrood and Westminster is based on an equal footing.For the first time she will today launch her initial lsquopartnership not hierarchyrsquo proposals for change to the Labour Party, which would involve creating a Chamber of the Nations and Regions to replace the House of Lords in a move that Baroness Bryan believes would mean the Scottish Parliament was no longer subordinate to Westminster.It comes as previously unreleased poll for the Electoral Reform Society by BMG shows that, when dont knows are excluded, support for an elected upper chamber sits at % for SNP voters and % for Conservatives.ERS says that suggest that Lords reform could be a vote winner for the party . A majority of all main partiesrsquo supporters backed an elected second chamber.The Bryan paper that kicks off Labours review of its constitutional policy is set to take the party much closer to backing full federalism and a new constitutional settlement for the UK "based on the commitment to redistribute power and wealth, and that takes account of the consequences of Brexit".In her analysis of future principles, she says a new federal set-up will "move from the existing model, where power is devolved from the central state to Scotland".Baroness Bryan, who is the designated lead for updating the partyrsquos policy on federalism and Lords reform says the lsquopartnershiprsquo model for Westminster and Scotland would be backed by the reformed second chamber.The peer adds: "The point is to change the relationship so that the Scottish Parliament is no longer subordinate to Westminster. A second chamber of the Regions and Nations would change the nature of the relations to shared government on the cross territorial issues."UK-wide, ldquoInstead of the House of Commons having automatic primacy, this would be a new settlement of shared sovereignty, Baroness Bryan says.She believes a reformed ndash most-likely directly elected ndash second chamber would have a key role in this, bringing the nations and regions together to agree what powers should be devolved and which should be shared.Willie Sullivan, director of ERS Scotland, said: ldquoThe piecemeal, ad hoc approach to democratic change in the UK has held us back, with a constant, low-level constitutional crisis: with Scotland and the other nations pitted against Westminster, and vice versa."That is not a sustainable relationship and it is time for an approach the puts citizens at the centre, not the needs of politicians. What form this reform takes is up for discussion, but it is good to see parties considering this in the round.ldquoAs this briefing points out, the primary way to reform the bloated, unelected House of Lords is to replace it with a fairly-elected revising chamber, with a clearly defined remit and which can speak up for the nations and regions of the whole UK."Voters are tired of seeing scandal after scandal in the Lords with no way of kicking them out. A much-smaller, more effective second chamber would help draw to a close the era of unaccountable power and bring our democracy into the st century.Bryans other key claims include concerns that the Scottish Parliament has gained additional powers in response to political pressures, which can be "curtailed as easily as they were granted".She says that while the Sewel convention established that Westminster would not legislate on devolved issues without the express consent of the Scottish Parliament, "we have seen from the repatriation of powers through Brexit that this may not always be adhered to".She also states that local government in Scotland has lost powers to increasing centralisation by the Scottish Government.Nancy Platts, co-ordinator of Politics for the Many ndash the trade union campaign for political reform ndash said: ldquoThis is a fundamental step [forward] in developing Labourrsquos thinking on constitutional reform. Labour must now adopt these proposals as the starting point to ensuring that our politics works for the many, not an unelected few.The report will be unveiled at a Labour fringe meeting titled: "Remaking the state: Transforming Scotland for Worker and Citizen Power".Mass poll by BMG for ERS. title: the-most-powerful-woman-in-uk-banking-unveils-her-plans-for-the-future
story: Now Alison Rose is determined that many other young women will follow in her footsteps and reach the top of their professions.As chief executive of RBSrsquos commercial and private banking arm, Ms Rose is making it her mission to change the male-dominated banking profession that she joined more than  years ago.When she attended her first meeting as a senior RBS executive, she was the only woman in the boardroom.Now, one-third of the top  posts are held by women, but Ms Rose wants to go further and hopes that she is the ideal role model for young females to look up to.She said: ldquoWe have made great strides but there is still a long way to go.ldquoI do see myself as a positive role model and I hope that young women will aspire to reach the top.ldquoI think that I am someone that can be looked up to.Ms Rose is widely-tipped to replace current chief executive Ross McEwan when he steps down, which is expected to be in .She refuses to be drawn on her potential succession as her total focus is on encouraging women at all levels of business, especially those looking to set up and run their own companies.Ms Rose said: ldquoWe currently have a very good CEO and Irsquom happy to be working for him.But she does acknowledge the seismic change that would be sent outshe were to become the first female head of a major high street bank in the UK.For her, it would send out the best possible message to the , extra women she wants to help set up their own business by .Currently, just one in three entrepreneurs is female, while in some other European countries the rate is more than  per cent.It is a situation that she is desperate to change and hopes her report will lead to a dramatic increase in female businesswomen.She said: ldquoThe review has proved what we all expected that the unrealised potential for the UK economy caused by the disparity between male and female entrepreneurs is considerable.ldquoThe scale of the ambition is considerable and in my view we now have our North Star to aim for, a % increase in female entrepreneurs.ldquoThat will act as a guide to joined up action across public and private sector.Women make up more than half the population in Britain, but just one in five businesses is female-run, a figure recently described as ldquoshocking by Robert Jenrick, exchequer secretary to the Treasury.Research suggests one in eight working women would like to start a business but the Entrepreneurs Network reports that just nine per cent of funding for UK start-ups goes to women, and that men are  per cent more likely to be funded by venture capital.With Ms Rosersquos encouragement, RBS has created a network of  NatWest Entrepreneur Accelerator hubs around the country.These are where would-be entrepreneurs can get help with the nuts and bolts of finding start-up funds and writing business plans from a team of women advisers.The Treasury review is her first foray into the public realm for Ms Rose, who has two children ndash a daughter, , and son, .She said: ldquoItrsquos a big responsibility but itrsquos something I feel passionately aboutldquoThe most important thing to remember is that itrsquos never perfect.ldquoEven when yoursquove got support and yoursquore very organised, things always go wrong. It is a juggling, balancing and complicated act.She joined National Westminster Bank as a trainee in  after graduating from Durham University.By the time RBS took over NatWest in , Ms Rose was working her way through a series of jobs in the investment banking ision, which ultimately put her in charge of leveraged finance in the UK and Europe.She helped restructure the balance sheet in the aftermath of the financial implosion and in  took over commercial and private banking, which now accounts for nearly half of assets at the group.She refused to be drawn on the bankrsquos major challenges in the coming months, particularly with Brexit.The bank has already relocated some jobs to Amsterdam in case of a no-deal exit.Ms Rose admits that while RBS has restored some of its badly tarnished reputation there is still some way to go.She said: ldquoItrsquos been a very dficult time but we are working hard to restore it by trying to improve things for customers. I believe we have made a lot of progress in improving things, but we are not complacent.And it seems she sees it as her responsibility to inspire others too.One major area that needs to be addressed, according to Ms Rose, is getting girls exposed to female entrepreneurs and get them interested in Stem subjects which offer the highest growth for businesses.RBS is now going to increase engagement in schools by rolling-out a groundbreaking pilot scheme that focuses on entrepreneurship, financial literacy and self-belief.Ms Rose said: ldquoThere are not enough women in high-growth fields and that is also holding many back.ldquoBy going into schools then we can provide young girls with a role model they need to aspire too. By the time they get to college it is normally too late.ldquoThere are real and practical steps that can and will be taken. Maintaining the status quo is not an option.

title: richard-leonard-to-tell-labour-supporters-we-make-our-own-history
story: Richard Leonard will insist there is ldquono inevitability to Labour once again forming a government north of the border ndash but that this can be achievedthe party ldquowork for it.Labour was the main partner in a coalition administration with the Lib Dems for the first eight years after the Scottish Parliament was restored, winning Holyrood elections in  and .But it lost out to the SNP in  and has not been in power since, with the party now only the third largest at Holyrood behind the Scottish Tories.More recently, the SNP has come under fire over its record on the NHS and education, with rivals accusing Nicola Sturgeonrsquos party of being too focused on the constitution.Mr Leonard will tell the Scottish Labour conference in Dundee: ldquoWe cannot rely on an automatic disillusionment with the SNP to do the job for us. There is no iron law, there is no inevitability.ldquoButwe work for it, industrially and politically, we can achieve it. Because I tell you, we make our own history.ldquoWe are getting back to where we always should have been, the party of communities and the party of workers.However, the three-day conference is taking place at a time when the leadership of Mr Leonard and Jeremy Corbyn is coming under fire.Mr Corbyn has been criticised for failing to do enough to tackle anti-Semitism, with Mr Leonard saying on Friday that a lack of resources was delaying the investigation of complaints.Several MPs have quit UK Labour because of the issue and the partyrsquos stance on Brexit while Mr Leonard has been accused of attempting to censor his partyrsquos two Scottish MEPs.In his conference speech, the Scottish leader will set out his ldquoprogressive agenda for workersrsquo rights ndash and also call on the Scottish Government to do more.Mr Leonard will say: ldquoThe SNP tell us we shouldnrsquot talk about workersrsquo rights because they are reserved. But these practices are commonplace on public contracts funding by the Scottish Government.ldquoWhich is why it is about time that we had a Scottish Government that was prepared to use its powers, including through public procurement, to drive up employment standards and working practices on these contracts to build our hospitals, to build our roads and to build our railway infrastructure.

title: rising-number-of-film-companies-setting-up-in-scotland
story: Last year there were  film and video companies registered in Scotland, up from  in .The figures, released by the Scottish Parliament, have been welcomed by the SNP.HoweverGillian Martin MSP warned the industry is concerned by the potential impact of Brexit.Filming major productions including the Fast  Furious spin-off Hobbs  Shaw brought just over pound million to Glasgowrsquos economy last year.Other productions to have sought out Scotland as a location include Netflixrsquos Outlaw King and hit TV series Outlander.Ms Martin said: ldquoThe film industry employs thousands of people in Scotland and wersquore increasingly seen as a destination location for major productions.ldquoAs well as the direct economic impact of the industry, therersquos no greater advert for Scotland as a tourist destination than our cities and landscapes being shown on the big screen.ldquoThe SNP in government is committed to supporting our screen sector but, like all creative industries, there are serious concerns over the impact of Brexit.ldquoItrsquos shameful that, just three weeks until wersquore expected to leave the EU, businesses and workers still have absolutely no clarity on what Brexit will look like.ldquoItrsquos time to press pause on Brexit and go back to the people.

title: technical-solutions-could-avoid-infrastructure-on-irish-border-post-brexit-say-mps
story: A highly sophisticated ldquoworld first would be necessary to achieve such a system during a -month transition period after an orderly exit, the Westminster inquiry found.It could include a mobile phone identication system enabling remote ID checking as well as a previously suggested trusted trader scheme, expert evidence to the Government scrutiny body said.The Northern Ireland Affairs Committee also called on UK and EU negotiators to agree on a definition of a hard border.Chairman Andrew Murrison said: ldquoMy committeetook good evidence to suggest that technical and systems-based solutions to ensure the border looks and feels as it does today are do-able but they require trust and goodwill.Unless something changes, the UK is set to exit the EU without a deal later this month.Avoiding a hard border and resolving the dispute over the ldquobackstop insurance policy keeping Northern Ireland in line with EU regulationsno other trade solution is foundis the key sticking point in reaching agreement before March .The committee published its report on Saturday.It took evidence fromthe former director of capacity building at the World Customs Organisation, Lars Karlsson, on proposals for managing the flow of goods on the island of Ireland.Mr Karlsson saidall the separate elements which make up the proposal ldquohave been tested somewhere in the world just not in one single border and the border in Northern Ireland would be ldquothe first and a leading example in the world of this kind.His proposal included:ndash A bilateral EU-UK agreement on advanced customs cooperationndash Mutual recognition of trusted tradersndash A technical agreement on exchange of customs risk datandash An identication system by the border using either the mobile phone network or radio frequency identication to check goods or driver ID without leaving the vehiclendash A digital single entry point for traders addressing import and export mattersndash Creation of a unique consignment reference numberndash A simplied electronic customs declaration systemndash Mobile control and inspection unitsndash Border surveillance using automated number plate recognition and CCTV.Mr Murrison said:ldquoTime is running out toreachcommon ground.ldquoThere should be no attempt to use the border as a lever or as a way of securing political advantage.ldquoMistrust over the backstop protocol has been heightened by lack of clarity onwhat exactly constitutes a lsquohard border.rsquoldquoMy committee is calling for claricationof the term in a legally explicit way to ensure both parties share the same understanding of how the backstop can be avoided.

title: climber-from-the-highlands-lost-his-mother-on-k2
story: Briton Tom Ballard, whose mother died on K, was climbing Nanga Parbat in Pakistan with Italian Daniele Nardi when they lost contact on February .A search operation was under way this week after four Spanish rescuers were flown to the area by military helicopter on Monday and were joined by Pakistani mountaineer Ali Sadpara at base camp.Italian ambassador Stefano Pontecorvo said that the search team has confirmed that silhouettes spotted on the mountain were the bodies of Mr Ballard and Mr Nardi.He tweeted: "With great sadness I inform that the search for @NardiDaniele and Tom Ballard is over as @AlexTxikon and the search team have confirmed that the silhouettes spotted on Mummery at about  meters are those of Daniele and Tom. R.I.P."He said that the bodies are in a place that is dficult to reach but that everything possible will be done to try and recover them.Mr Ballard was born in Derbyshire but moved to the Scottish Highlands in , the year his mother, Alison Hargreaves, died on K when she was , months after becoming the first woman to conquer Everest unaided.Despite being dubbed "Killer Mountain" because of its dangerous conditions, the summit of Nanga Parbat has long drawn climbers.Located in Pakistans Gilgit Baltistan area, it is the ninth highest mountain in the world at , metres .Mr Nardi and Mr Ballard set out on the climb on February , making it to the fourth base camp by the following day.The pair last made contact on February  from an elevation of around , meterson Nanga Parbat.Pakistan dispatched search helicopters last week despite the closure of its airspace amid tensions with neighbouring India over the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir.Mr Pontecorvo said that the search team involving the Spaniards this week captured photos of the silhouettes and analysis confirmed that they were the missing climbers.Mr Nardi, , from near Rome, had attempted the Nanga Parbat summit in winter several times in the past.In  Mr Ballard became the first person ever to solo climb all six major north faces of the Alps in one winter.

title: yes-digital-chief-criticises-wings-over-scotland-and-cybernats-over-indyref
story: In an interview for a BBC documentary, Stewart Kirkpatrick said that ldquoexpletive littered rants from Wings Over Scotland were ldquoreally not helpful.He added that the so-called ldquocybernats- online Nationalists who round on critics of the SNP and independence - ldquounequivocally hurt his cause.Entitled lsquoYes No ndash Inside The Indyrefrsquo, the three part series on the  referendum was made by Paul Mitchell, whose previous work includes lsquoInside Obamarsquos White Housersquo and lsquoThe Death of Yugoslaviarsquo.The first part, screened last week, focused on the deal struck between the Scottish and UK Governments which paved the way for a plebiscite.The second instalment, which will be broadcast this week, contains exclusive interviews with key players on the two head-to-head debates between Alex Salmond and Alistair Darling, who was chair of the pro-UK Better Together.It also concentrates on the influence of social media in helping both sides get their message across to voters.The Yes Scotland campaign was regarded as having an impressive social media offering, but critics believed the official messaging was undermined by the aggression of the cybernats.Wings over Scotland, a website run by Bath-based Stuart Campbell, became a popular resource for some pro-independence supporters who were frustrated with newspapers and the BBC.However, some of Campbellrsquos output also frustrated figures in the Yes movement who believed it turned off floating voters.In an interview for the documentary, Stewart Kirkpatrick, who was Yes Scotlands head of digital, said that a Wings pamphlet on independence had been a ldquostroke of genius, but said:ldquoThe impact of Wings  Are we talking about the Wings over Scotland who is the data-driven journalist, who gets to the annoying nugget and writes a piece around it and canrsquot be argued with  Or is it the guy who refers to Tory politicians as troughing scum and goes on expletive littered rants on Twitter  This guy was very helpful, this guy really wasnrsquot.Speaking generally, he added: ldquoThe cybernat thing definitely hurt us. Unequivocally. People being abusive online did not help the Yes campaign.Campbell was also interviewed and spoke about why he set up Wings over Scotland: ldquoVery early on I realised how bad the newspaper coverage was, how bad the tv coverage was.He also said: ldquoOther countries, independence campaigns, have waded knee deep in blood. All we did was occasionally call each other some names on Twitter. The idea that Scottish people are shocked by a few swear words is laughable.Meanwhile, the documentary also revealed the anguish of Salmondrsquos key advisers after they watched their boss perform badly in the first debate with Darling.Salmond was expected to win the debate, but he noseed after focusing on what he regarded as Unionist scare stories about outer space and Scots having to drive on the right hand side of the road.Geoff Aberdein, who was Salmondrsquos chief of staff, said he was ldquodevastated by the performance: ldquoI walked into an adjacent auditoriumhellip.and just put my head in my hands for a good forty minutes.Kevin Pringle, who was Salmondrsquos trusted spin doctor, added: ldquoIt just didnrsquot really work terribly well.Salmond, in his own interview, admitted making a ldquomistake, adding: ldquoItrsquos like having a great idea last thing at night. Itrsquos less a good idea in the morning.However, Salmond performed better in the second debate and was judged to have beaten Darling.

title: sir-cliff-richard-backs-pressure-group-pushing-for-anonymity-reform
story: In  his Berkshire home was raided by police, which was covered by the BBC and included the deployment of a TV helicopter, and led to him being publicly named.No arrests were made in relation to the accusation against Sir Clf, and he did not face charges.Sir Clf is now backing Falsely Accused Iniduals for Reform , a new pressure group that is pushing for anonymity for those accused of sexual offences until there is a charge.ldquoBeing ly accused myself and having that exposed in the media was the worst thing that has happened to me in my entire le, Sir Clf said.ldquoEven though untrue, the stigma is almost impossible to eradicate.ldquoHence the importance of Fairrsquos campaign to change the law to provide for anonymity before charge in sexual allegations and hence my continued work with Fair in the future.ldquoHad this proposed change in the law been enacted when the police decided to raid my apartment following the allegations of a fantasist, the BBC would not have been able to film this event, name me,and so plunge my le and those close to me into fear and misery.He previously said that the trauma of the coverage left him emotionally drained. The singer has since sued the BBC for invasion of privacy ndash winning pound, in damages.Daniel Janner QC, whose father was the late Labour peer Lord Janner, is the founder and secretary of Fair.The group strongly believes in anonymity up until charge, and is also calling for a change in the language of criminal proceedings from victims to complainants.Mr Janner described Sir Clfrsquos support as an ldquoenormous boost to our important work.ldquoIt is a privilege and honour that Sir Clf has added his support. We campaign to re-balance the scales of justice to protect those ly accused, he said.ldquoAt present we are concentrating our efforts to change the law to provide for anonymity until charge for those accused of sexual offences.Other Fair supporters include broadcaster Paul Gambaccini who was arrested in October  over a claim he sexually assaulted two teenage boys as part of Operation Yewtree, set up in the wake of the revelations about paedophile Jimmy Savile.The -year-old, a regular fixture on the airwaves for decades, spent a year on bail before the case was dropped.Former Tory MP Harvey Proctor had his home raided and was publicly named, and is also a supporter of the pressure group.He was investigated as part of Scotland Yardrsquos doomed sex abuse probe Operation Midland that centred on claims boys were sexually abused by a number of public figures more than  years ago.The investigation was abandoned amid widespread criticism, with the -year-old spending more than a year facing accusations he was a child murderer and rapist before he was finally cleared.

title: john-mcdonnell-says-labour-is-preparing-for-government
story: While Labour have been trailing the Conservatives in the polls, Mr McDonnell said: ldquoWe need another two to three points to take us into government and that is what we will get when we go into that campaign.With Theresa Mayrsquos Tories no longer having a Commons majority, the shadow chancellor said that Parliament ldquois so unstable it is completely unpredictable.And he told a fringe event at the Scottish Labour conference in Dundee that he and Jeremy Corbyn were already preparing for government.While he accepted it was ldquoalmost impossible for Labour to force a general election under the current system of fixed term parliaments, Mr McDonnell said: ldquoJust in case there is an election we are preparing for an election, wersquove got all the campaign plans ready. Wersquove been testing messaging, wersquove got the grid ready to go.ldquoThe grid is who goes where in terms of shadow cabinet all round the country, where Jeremyrsquos rallies are going to be, sothere is a general election we go straight into election mode.Mr McDonnell also told Labour activiststhat as part of the preparations he was now considering his first budget.He said: ldquoIrsquom going through a first budget exercise, so Irsquom sitting down with all the shadow cabinet teams to talk about their plans, costing them and then look at priorities.ldquoWersquore in that situation where literally wersquore preparing for government, wersquore preparing for the election.

title: philip-hammond-in-200m-boost-for-scientific-research
story: Philip Hammond said the additional funding would help maintain the UKrsquos ldquopole position in technological innovation as the country prepares to leave the EU.The Government is committed to raising investment in research and development to .% of GDP through its industrial strategy.Among the projects to benefit from the latest cash injection will be the Harwell Campus in Oxfordshire, which will receive pound million for work developing state-of-the-art laser technology.The research will help understand how particular materials react in dferent conditions, such as a replacement joint when it is inserted into the human body.A further pound million will go to develop a new national ldquosuper-computer in Edinburgh, five times quicker than the UKrsquos current capabilities.It will be used across a range of research programmes including medicine, climate science and aerospace, while building on previous British breakthroughs in targeted treatments for arthritis and HIV.There will be another pound million for genetic research in Cambridge, providing additional computing and storage capacity.It will support efforts to sequence one million genomes ndash a world first ndash and to explore innovative cell therapies to tackle genetic diseases.Mr Hammond said: ldquoUK scientic research is worth pound billion and is at the cutting edge of international innovation and discovery.ldquoWe want to retain pole position as we leave the EU, and the announcements I make next week will ensure we maintain our competitive advantage.ldquoThese investments will support innovators across the country to make the breakthroughs that will push biotechnology, medicine, science and aerospace forward.The move comes as the Treasury has sought to play down expectations of major spending announcements in the Spring Statement, which is expected to focus mainly on the latest economic forecasts.

title: chancellor-philip-hammond-accused-of-penalising-scots
story: He said that ldquoScotland is once again losing out on vital funding, calling on Mr Hammond to recty this when he makes his Spring Statement to the Commons on Wednesday.The Finance Secretary demanded Scotland receive cash to mitigate the impact of Brexit and also to ldquounequivocally end the decade of austerity which the UK Government has imposed on Scotland.With the Spring Statement taking place at the same time as a number of key Brexit votes in Parliament, Mr Mackay also urged the Chancellor to immediately rule out any prospect of the UK leaving the European Union without a deal in place, and to extend the Article  timetable for negotiations.Britain is due to quit the EU on March , and Mr Mackay noted Scotland had been allocated more than pound billion in the current European budget round.He said: ldquoIt is crucial that the UK Government urgently commits to replacing all funding streams in full, and that we receive our fair share of this to ensure that decisions can be taken in the best interests of the Scottish economy and Scottish people.The pound billion funding deal for Northern Ireland after the Democratic Unionist Party agreed to support Theresa Mayrsquos minority government should have resulted in pound. billion for Scotland,the Barnett formula had been applied, the Finance Secretary added.He went on to urge Mr Hammond to repay pound million in VAT payments made by Police Scotland and the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service after the unitary authorities were set up.Other demands included the Scottish National Investment Bank being granted the same financial flexibility as the British Business Bank, and for the UK Government to fully match the investment the Scottish Government is making in city region deals.In his letter Mr Mackay told the Chancellor: ldquoI strongly encourage you to use this fiscal headroom to ensure that the Scottish Government has the resources at its disposal over the coming months to mitigate the damage that the UK Governmentrsquos approach to Brexit is causing to our economy.ldquoI also urge you to use the Spring Statement to confirm that additional funding will be provided through the next Spending Review to unequivocally end the decade of austerity which the UK Government has imposed on Scotland.Overall the Finance Secretary claimed: ldquoScotland is once again losing out on vital funding and being shortchanged by the UK Government. The Chancellor must use his Spring Statement to address this imbalance which is penalising people across Scotland.ldquoThe decision in  to allocate pound billion exclusively to Northern Ireland without consequentials to the other devolved administrations is yet to be resolved, and it is unacceptable for the UK Government to continue to provide additional funding for devolved services in Northern Ireland without applying the Barnett formula.ldquoThis, along with the latest funding for Northern Ireland, has meant that Scotland has lost out on equivalent funding of around pound. billion.ldquoIn addition, analysis by the Scottish Government shows that a disorderly no-dearsquo Brexit has the potential to generate a signicant economic shock and tip the Scottish economy into recession.ldquoThe UK Government must rule out no deal at any time and request an immediate extension of Article .

title: muslim-leader-urges-bangladesh-to-take-in-is-runaway-shamima-begum
story: The Home Secretary was under renewed scrutiny on Saturday after it emerged the teenagerrsquos weeks-old son died in a Syrian refugee camp.Ms Begum, who fled London to join the terror group aged
